actions-list.actionItem: Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 580, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Stevens amendment No. 278.

An amendment, offered by Mr. Steube,  numbered 278 printed in Part A of House Report 119-199 to increase by $10 million to accelerate the procurement of portable water storage and distribution systems for the Army to replace aging legacy equipment.
By unanimous consent, the Miller-Meeks amendment was withdrawn.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 580, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Miller-Meeks amendment No. 221.
An amendment, offered by Mrs. Miller-Meeks,  numbered 221 printed in Part A of House Report 119-199 to prohibit funds from being used to reduce the workforce at any active United States Army arsenal.
On agreeing to the Joyce (PA) amendment; Agreed to by voice vote.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 580, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Joyce (PA) amendment No. 159.

An amendment, offered by Mr. Joyce (PA),  numbered 159 printed in Part A of House Report 119-199 to increase the amount for Heavy Dump Truck, 20T (CCE), Other Procurement, Army Budget Activity by $30 million and decrease the amount for development of the Future Tactical Unmanned Aircraft System, Research, Development, Test, and Evaluation, Army by $30 million.

At the conclusion of debate on the Greene (GA) amendment No. 116, the Chair put the question on agreeing to the amendment and by voice vote, announced the noes had prevailed. Mr. Greene (GA) demanded a recorded vote, and the Chair postponed further proceedings until a time to be announced.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 580, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Greene (GA) amendment No. 116.
An amendment, offered by Ms. Greene (GA),  numbered 116 printed in Part A of House Report 119-199 to strike funds from being used for assistance to Ukraine.

At the conclusion of debate on the Greene (GA) amendment No. 115, the Chair put the question on agreeing to the amendment and by voice vote, announced the noes had prevailed. Ms. Greene (GA) demanded a recorded vote, and the Chair postponed further proceedings until a time to be announced.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 580, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Greene (GA) amendment No. 115.
An amendment, offered by Ms. Greene (GA),  numbered 115 printed in Part A of House Report 119-199 to strike funding to support the armed forces of Jordan.

At the conclusion of debate on the Greene (GA) amendment No. 114, the Chair put the question on agreeing to the amendment and by voice vote, announced the noes had prevailed. Ms. Greene (GA) demanded a recorded vote, and the Chair postponed further proceedings until a time to be announced.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 580, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Greene (GA) amendment No. 114.
An amendment, offered by Ms. Greene (GA),  numbered 114 printed in Part A of House Report 119-199 to strike funding for the Israeli Cooperative Programs.

At the conclusion of debate on the Greene (GA) amendment No. 113, the Chair put the question on agreeing to the amendment and by voice vote, announced the noes had prevailed. Ms. Greene (GA) demanded a recorded vote, and the Chair postponed further proceedings until a time to be announced.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 580, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Greene (GA) amendment No. 113.
An amendment, offered by Ms. Greene (GA),  numbered 113 printed in Part A of House Report 119-199 to strike funding for HIV prevention educational activities in foreign countries.

At the conclusion of debate on the Greene (GA) amendment No. 112, the Chair put the question on agreeing to the amendment and by voice vote, announced the noes had prevailed. Ms. Greene (GA) demanded a recorded vote, and the Chair postponed further proceedings until a time to be announced.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 580, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Greene (GA) amendment No. 112.
An amendment, offered by Ms. Greene (GA),  numbered 112 printed in Part A of House Report 119-199 to strike funding for the Taiwan Security Cooperation Initiative.

At the conclusion of debate on the Greene (GA) amendment No. 111, the Chair put the question on agreeing to the amendment and by voice vote, announced the noes had prevailed. Ms. Greene (GA) demanded a recorded vote, and the Chair postponed further proceedings until a time to be announced.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 580, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Greene (GA) amendment No. 111.

An amendment, offered by Ms. Greene (GA),  numbered 111 printed in Part A of House Report 119-199 to reduce funding for "overseas humanitarian, disaster, and civic aid" to be in line with the administration's budget request, and transfer the savings to the Spending Reduction Account.
On agreeing to the Gosar amendment; Failed by voice vote.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 580, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Gosar amendment No. 106.

An amendment, offered by Mr. Gosar,  numbered 106 printed in Part A of House Report 119-199 to prohibit funds for BioMADE, a bioindustrial manufacturer that produces lab-grown meat for military bases.
On agreeing to the Davidson amendment; Failed by voice vote.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 580, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Davidson amendment No. 57.
An amendment, offered by Mr. Davidson,  numbered 57 printed in Part A of House Report 119-199 to strike the provision barring the Navy from decommissioning Littoral Combat Ships.
The House resolved into Committee of the Whole House on the state of the Union for further consideration.
Considered as unfinished business. H.R. 4016 â€” "Making appropriations for the Department of Defense for the fiscal year ending September 30, 2026, and for other purposes."

At the conclusion of debate on H.R. 1919, the Chair put the question on passage of the bill and by voice vote, announced that the ayes had prevailed. Ms. Waters demanded the yeas and nays and the Chair postponed further proceedings until a time to be announced.
The previous question was ordered pursuant to the rule.
The House proceeded with one hour of debate on H.R. 1919.

Rule provides for consideration of H.R. 4016, H.R. 3633, H.R. 1919 and S. 1582. The resolution provides for consideration of H.R. 4016 and H.R. 3633 under a structured rule, and H.R. 1919 and S. 1582 under a closed rule, with one hour of general debate on each bill. The resolution provides for a motion to recommit on H.R. 4016, H.R. 3633, and H.R. 1919, and a motion to commit on S. 1582.

Considered under the provisions of rule H. Res. 580. H.R. 1919 â€” "To amend the Federal Reserve Act to prohibit the Federal reserve banks from offering certain products or services directly to an individual, to prohibit the use of central bank digital currency for monetary policy, and for other purposes."

At the conclusion of debate on S. 1582, the Chair put the question on passage of the bill and by voice vote, announced that the ayes had prevailed. Ms. Waters demanded the yeas and nays and the Chair postponed further proceedings until a time to be announced.
The previous question was ordered pursuant to the rule.
The House proceeded with one hour of debate on S. 1582.

Rule provides for consideration of H.R. 4016, H.R. 3633, H.R. 1919 and S. 1582. The resolution provides for consideration of H.R. 4016 and H.R. 3633 under a structured rule, and H.R. 1919 and S. 1582 under a closed rule, with one hour of general debate on each bill. The resolution provides for a motion to recommit on H.R. 4016, H.R. 3633, and H.R. 1919, and a motion to commit on S. 1582.
Considered under the provisions of rule H. Res. 580. S. 1582 â€” "To provide for the regulation of payment stablecoins, and for other purposes."

At the conclusion of debate on H.R. 3633, the Chair put the question on passage of the bill and by voice vote, announced that the ayes had prevailed. Ms. Craig demanded the yeas and nays and the Chair postponed further proceedings until a time to be announced.
The previous question was ordered pursuant to the rule.
The House proceeded with one hour of debate on H.R. 3633.

Rule provides for consideration of H.R. 4016, H.R. 3633, H.R. 1919 and S. 1582. The resolution provides for consideration of H.R. 4016 and H.R. 3633 under a structured rule, and H.R. 1919 and S. 1582 under a closed rule, with one hour of general debate on each bill. The resolution provides for a motion to recommit on H.R. 4016, H.R. 3633, and H.R. 1919, and a motion to commit on S. 1582.

Considered under the provisions of rule H. Res. 580. H.R. 3633 â€” "To provide for a system of regulation of the offer and sale of digital commodities by the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, and for other purposes."
The House proceeded with one minute speeches, which by direction of the Chair would be limited to 5 per side of the aisle.
The House received a message from the Senate. The Senate passed H.R. 4 amended.
The Chair designated Ms. Dean of PA to lead the Members in reciting the Pledge of Allegiance to the Flag.
The Speaker announced approval of the Journal.  Pursuant to clause 1, rule I, the Journal stands approved.
Today's prayer was offered by Rev. Dr. Lindsay Curtis, Grace Baptist Church, Norwalk, CT.
The House convened, starting a new legislative day.
